“I love seeing the joy on the students' faces when they get the book they have been dying to read!”

For the last four years, Jennifer McDonnell has served as our main volunteer librarian. Before Hawthorn opened in August 2015, she was collecting books to build our library. Because of her contribution and hard work, when our students walk into our library they can choose from hundreds of books. When not at Hawthorn, Mrs. McDonnell serves on national and local boards and sits on the Board of Scripps College in Claremont, California. Thank you to all volunteer librarians. Thanks to you, our students are able to find books they love.

“My favorite part about volunteering at Hawthorn is seeing my students succeed, especially at things they previously didn't know they were capable of. And seeing the really cool things that they create with programming.”

Kurt Glastetter works alongside Dr. Williams’ in our AP Computer Science Principles course as a Microsoft TEALS teaching assistant. TEALS is a program that pairs trained computer science professionals from the tech industry with classroom teachers to team-teach computer science. Kurt is here twice a week every week at 8 AM. When he leaves Hawthorn he goes to Riot Games where he works as a Software Engineer. With Kurt’s help, we have been able to teach rigorous computer science courses to our high school students. Thank you to Kurt and all our TEALS volunteers!

Our very own Executive Director, Dr. Sheri L. Miller has been selected to participate in a documentary and serve as a panelist at the upcoming 17th Annual Alumni of Color Conference at Harvard University’s Graduate School of Education March 1st & 2nd. The session entitled, “This is Us: The Experiences of Black Girls in the American Education System,” will highlight the varied academic and social experiences of Black girls in schools across America.

A powerful documentary will set the stage with an authentic portrayal of expressions from Black women and girls regarding their educational experiences. The esteemed panel hopes to identify a common theme throughout the stories, and leverage research related to identifying ways to deconstruct systems that have so negatively influenced some of the academic experiences and personal narratives of Black girls.

We are certain Dr. Miller will bring the essence of her more than twenty-eight years of urban education experience to Harvard University.

Get to know the staff and faculty of Hawthorn with our weekly #humansofhawthorn series.

Today, we introduce Katie Herring, who is an eighth and ninth grade humanities teacher. Ms. Herring is the oldest of four daughters, so sisterhood is something that runs throughout her life. She is a proud graduate of Southeast Missouri State University, and this is her 6th year teaching. She taught for three years on the Rosebud Reservation in south-central South Dakota, and this is her second year teaching at Hawthorn. She loves teaching humanities because our stories and our voices matter. When Ms. Herring is not at school, she enjoys reading, going to the movies, trying new restaurants and wandering around her neighborhood. She cannot wait to see how her students' voices shape the world.
